summary: Dr. Génessier (Pierre Brasseur) is riddled with guilt after an accident that he caused disfigures the face of his daughter, the once beautiful Christiane (Édith Scob), who outsiders believe is dead. Dr. Génessier, along with accomplice and laboratory assistant Louise (Alida Valli), kidnaps young women and brings them to the Génessier mansion. After rendering his victims unconscious, Dr. Génessier removes their faces and attempts to graft them on to Christiane's.

reviews.content: A great concept and some good memerable parts that make you feel uneasy such as the surgery scenes but the rest was forgettable. There was not much in the way of likeable or interesting characters.
This film is a groundbreaking thriller for the time it was released.
It's really slow and boring by today's standards but it's still artistic and has a clever idea. It's more of a thriller then a horror film so it's not very scary.

Grotesquely made with dated fright but withstood compellingly and creepily only progressively shortened to the minimum. This may be due to a visiting genre expectation generated by the frontal focus's first picturesque impression as a visual selling factor, only to find it bland and morbid enough to overshadow its perceived praiseworthy poeticism. (B-)

On of the most artistic Horror films I've seen to date, Eyes Without a Face examines a doctor's guilt and obsession with fixing his daughter's mutilated face. It was the father who caused the disfigured face of the young daughter and he is so obsessed that he seeks to fix her face himself. In order to do this he has his mistress, whose face he repaired, scope out and lure young beautiful women back to the doctor's secluded home. At this home the doctor has a secret lab behind trap doors and hidden in the basement. It's here that the young women are sedated and their faces cut off in order to give his daughter the face she had lost. The film is amazing to behold and presents a disturbed man and his terrifying quest that consumes him. The dark and wonderfully filmed settings and imagery are what really elevates the film above and beyond most other in the genre. Highly recommended to horror fans and anyone that enjoys a tale of the macabre.

It's probably misleading to label Georges Franju's Eyes Without a Face a horror movie, but there is no doubt that the subject matter is horrific.  When his daughter's face is horribly disfigured in a car accident, a doctor begins kidnapping young women in order to murder them and surgically graft their faces onto his daughter's.  It's incredibly macabre throughout, an atmospheric thriller that relies on manipulating the viewer's imagination instead of showing the audience all of the gruesome details – with the exception, of course, of the actual face removal surgery.  Other than the music score, which sounds like something you'd hear at a circus, it's hard to find fault with this influential and unique film.
As far as creepy horror and suspense stories go, this film is amazing. It’s just enough - and horrific. Even today, fifty years later.

While it’s not quite as disturbing as some of today’s more “extreme” horror, ‘Eyes Without a Face’ was a shocking milestone in horror, and it still holds up today, providing a great blend of gruesome visuals and psychological torment.

This is just constantly unsettling. Edith Scob as the masked daughter is chilling, tragic and captivating just using her eyes. The camerawork is excellent (Shuftan, what do you expect?), the film constantly dislocates and the imagery moves from the sublime to the unbearable. The surgical scene is disturbing, but the ending is both terrible (the dogs) and beautiful (the doves).

I'm still processing the fact that this was released in 1960. Wow. 

Georges Franju's amazingly crafted a gothic and somber fairytale, that gave me some Frankenstein feels. Its exquisite and haunting photography is just poetry for the eye. It's all about shade and light to bring in the chills. The pace is also worth a mention. I was at the edge of my seat (bed) the whole time, and every time it got slow, the payoffs compensated it. Halloween and Friday the 13th surely exploited the effective white mask technique.
I absolutely adore this movie

There's a good argument that the 1960 French film Eyes Without a Face is more of a thriller with horror elements than an all-out horror movie. However you classify it, Eyes Without a Face is a peculiar film with haunting imagery. Since its addition to the Criterion Collection and late-night airings on TCM, it has become almost like required viewing for fans of classic horror and international horror films. Eyes Without a Face could qualify as "arthouse horror," or "elevated horror," but watching it isn't like doing homework. Eyes Without a Face is its own brand of horror.

After a car accident disfigures Christiane (Edith Scob), her father, Dr. Genessier (Pierre Brasseur), a renowned plastic surgeon, fakes her death and keeps her locked away at their country estate. He makes her wear an expressionless white mask and conducts experimental surgeries to restore her face. Dr. Genessier is acting entirely on his own wishes, not his daughter's; he mentions briefly that he is responsible for the accident that maimed her. Dr. Genessier's loyal and murderous assistant, Louise (Alida Valli), preys on young women to lure to the chateau for the doctor to use in his experiments. Christiane wants none of this, but she is a prisoner in her own home.

There are elements of body horror in Eyes Without a Face though it is not as graphic or explicit as the modern era films of David Cronenberg or Guillermo Del Toro. However, there is a prolonged scene of surgery where a girl's face is removed that is graphic and gross. It is not played for sensation but coldly and clinically without any background music and very few cuts. The horror of the scene comes from its context. There is nothing sadistic to the surgery, Dr. Genessier is just doing his work. The final moments of the film are filled with eerie and creepy imagery beautifully shot in stark black and white.

This is a good film to watch with someone that doesn't like horror movies but wants to watch something spooky. It is totally unlike anything resembling a conventional horror movie. There are no pop-up scares. The villains are not especially devilish or sadistic. The climax where Christiane finally takes agency of her own fate is played low-key. There is a detached feeling between the film and its macabre subject matter. It also has the structure of a mystery/thriller though we the audience know every angle of the story. Christiane's fiancé believes she is still alive and detectives are on the case of the missing girls, but these elements are in the far background.

Eyes Without a Face straddles the thriller and horror genres and also the classic and modern film eras. The unsensational, almost documentary-like approach to the story and characters lean towards the trends and style of the French New Wave being pioneered at the time by Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard. The score, however, is firmly rooted in the older era of filmmaking and feels too jaunty at times for what is happening on screen. The Criterion Collection, dedicated to highlighting notable classic and modern films, has few horror films in its library. I'm glad this is one of them.

even though i went into this with a lower set of expectations because, ya know, the 60's; but even so, nothing really happens. they do show her actual face once & to be honest it's not that bad. the mask she wears could be creepy, but she's such a nice character that it really just feels like she's wearing a beauty mask or something instead. you do see him cut a face off of a woman, but again - looks like one of those sheet masks you can buy at Walmart. it's hard to be phased by these older movies because the genre has just changed SO much - but i can see where this would be quite unnerving when it came out.

Its slow pace may bore some, but Eyes Without a Face is a compelling horror-drama that while it has a couple gruesome scenes for 1960, I found it to be a more affecting drama than a chilling horror movie.
this film is totally dark and scary I scared to death
Excellent horror movie, genuinely creepy.

I feel that Eyes Without a Face is a distinct work in horror film, with its combination of a slow, deliberate tone and the exploration of the actions taken by Doctor Génessier, including both the brutal, literal consequences contrasted with the innocent nature of the victims, as well as the often compassionate (yet undebiably flawed, guilty, and self-serving) nature of the perpetrator; his personality is far mroe complex than that of the prototypical mad scientist. The events of the film don't so much thrill, as make the stomach turn uncomfortably. Still, it's an arthouse film, with all the preconceptions that such an identity entails to contend with. To me, the use of unpolished, simple cuts between scenes (and the lack of color) evokes earlier silent horror films, at least in small doses. (3.5/5)
There are certainly horror elements here but I wouldn't consider this a horror film. Nonetheless, it's well-done and has an interesting story that isn't too drawn out.

Get those eyes a face!

I liked the eerie soundtrack and the light, ethereal quality of Christiane's agency, in the climactic scenes, emerging out of the horror to which she had been party.

Eyes Without a face is a highly atmospheric horror film from France. A surgeon and his apprentice abduct women off the streets and then perform a facial surgery to graft their skin on a woman they have kept imprisoned. Saying anything more would be doing disservice to the film but here is what I can say: This is a haunting film full of intense atmosphere right from the location and setting to the method by which most actors enact their characters. The music also adds to the surreal nature and if such films with surrealistic images and intense atmosphere (which take preceding over plot or character) than this should be a must watch on your list.(French horror filled with art and atmosphere).
Beautifully disturbing and disturbingly beautiful. Only way I can describe it.

This is an artsy horror film from France made in 1960. A surgeon and his apprentice abduct women off the streets and then perform a facial surgery to graft their skin on a woman they have kept imprisoned. Saying anything more would be doing disservice to the film but here is what I can say: This is a haunting film full of intense atmosphere right from the location and setting to the method by which most actors enact their characters. The music also adds to the surreal nature and if such films with surrealistic images and intense atmosphere (which take preceding over plot or character) than this should be a must watch on your list.

This is an artsy horror film from France made in 1960. A surgeon and his apprentice abduct women off the streets and then perform a facial surgery to graft their skin on a woman they have kept imprisoned. Saying anything more would be doing disservice to the film but here is what I can say: This is a haunting film full of intense atmosphere right from the location and setting to the method by which most actors enact their characters. The music also adds to the surreal nature and if such films with surrealistic images and intense atmosphere (which take preceding over plot or character) than this should be a must watch on your list.

This is an artsy horror film from France made in 1960. A surgeon and his apprentice abduct women off the streets and then perform a facial surgery to graft their skin on a woman they have kept imprisoned. Saying anything more would be doing disservice to the film but here is what I can say: This is a haunting film full of intense atmosphere right from the location and setting to the method by which most actors enact their characters. The music also adds to the surreal nature and if such films with surrealistic images and intense atmosphere (which take preceding over plot or character) than this should be a must watch on your list.

I have heard a lot about "Eyes Without a Face".  All that I have heard is very good.  Critics call the movie one of the most frightening horror films ever made and how well it has held up nearly six decades after it was released.  All of this positive feedback definitely sparked my interest in seeing the film.  I must tell you that all of the accolades given to this movie are not at all deserved.  Though the movie is well acted, and there are a few frightening scenes that are well made, I found I was bored more than I was frightened.  Mind you there are two rather scary scenes.  The first one being the scene where we see the doctor perform the transplant surgery.  Another is seeing the doctor dispose of the bodies fo the women he has kidnapped for his experiments.  However Those are the only times I was spooked watching this film.  Edith Scob does very well as Christiane, the daughter who's face was badly disfigured in a car crash caused by her father's negligence, but hers was the only performance that did not seem formulaic.  Also the movie leaves many unanswered questions at the end.  "Eyes Without a Face" is considered a horror classic.  After seeing the film, I frankly can't understand why.

Cold, pitiless and forensic, Les Yeux Sans Visage is a movie that is hard to like. A grieving surgeon abducts pretty young women in order to remove their faces and transplant them to his disfigured daughter. None of the main characters have a hinterland or anything that would make them more than a cypher, with the result that it's hard to maintain interest.

Yes, the mask in Eyes Without a Face is creepy. And yes, the surgery scene is pretty realistic. However, other than that, this movie is fairly bland and somewhat repetitive. And now I can't seem to get that Billy Idol song out of my head.

Eyes Without A Face was a noticeable influence on, of all things, John Woo' Face/Off, among many others, especially in the horror genre. Not necessarily a horror film in itself, more a tale of grief and anguish, despair and the abandonment of hope. It has some great moments, especially the reveal of the heroines disfigured face, but the film suffers badly from its near-static pacing and crushing lifelessness. The editing is very poor, with constant black outs at inappropriate times, and some scenes are allowed to go on for an unnecessary amount of time. For example, we see the main character arrive at his home, drive into his garage, get out of his car, walk up the steps to his house, and all the way through his house until he reaches his daughter's bedroom. Did we really need to see all of that happening in real time? It gets better later as we see less extraneous events, but it results in the film being significantly longer than it needs to be. There's not much of an atmosphere, not much tension, and too often feels like a product of its time. Even the controversy it attracted back on original release doesn't feel warranted, as we really don't get to see much of a controversial nature. I think people maybe have badly overreacted. It's not a film I'd re-watch, or even suggest to a friend. It needs better pacing, better editing and an actual sense of urgency.

With a haunting score and a disturbing plot, this film can be quite anguishing sometimes, especially in an infamous heterografting operation scene, working pretty well despite its flaws (like the police coming up with a stupid plan that makes no sense once you think about it).

Creepy and slightly disturbing French horror film about a rogue surgeon who conducts facial transplants in the secrecy of his own home. This is a horror film from the early '60s and needless to say it does not require the instant gratification of the scare jump but rather the sight of a patient with a facial transplant moving eerily and poetically up a stairwell or into a room.

Eyes Without a Face is a bit too gross in its surgery sequence and the third act was badly paced, but the film is otherwise such a stellar, ahead of its time horror film that is both artistic and emotional in approach, but also horrific and filled with great genre thrills. The acting and direction are great, the effects are excellent, the score is gorgeous and the film is very memorable owing to a bunch of unforgettable sequences such as the aforementioned surgery one, the dog attack scene and the ending which is beautiful.

The movie does a great job at setting up what will be a great investigation and movie plot. It was very odd to see the doctor so emotionless when he sees his daughter's body. Kind of makes you wonder.

The almost Scooby-Doo sounding soundtrack lightens up the mood throughout the movie which is great because it can be atmospheric and creepy at times. Seeing the mask and outfit is pretty creepy. But at the same time it's almost like she's not wearing a mask at times.

I can kind of see how the original Bioshock and Infinite could have been inspired by this movie. Specifically the relationship between the doctor and his daughter. As well as the obsessive doctor who seeks perfection in all his facial surgeries that he does.

That surgery scene will forever be ingrained in my memory. It was so uncomfortable and uneasy to watch. Even though you knew and looked like a mask, when they we're peeling it off, it still looked pretty damn good. Great make up effects.

This movie is great because instead of the "monster" being the evil or bad one, it's actually the ones who are taking care of the monster. In this case, Christiane's father and her mother figure. While Christiane, the "monster" is the one who in the end wants to put things right.

Quite a beautiful ending, other than the doctor's face. Kind of funny too given that the dove took a crap on her arm. But beautiful nonetheless because it's stating that Christiane has come to terms with her deformity and will now lead a life of peace among animals and nature. I wish the best for her.

Overall, wonderful horror film with an interesting story line and great performances.



What an interestingly macabre but jaunty piece of music they decided to open with during the credits. Complimenting the music but in a more darker, ominous way are the continuous shots of the trees in the dark that are lit by only the headlights of the car. It's interesting how the dark ominous imagery juxtaposes the sort of playful but macabre music. The music reminds me of Scooby-Doo lol. 

What an odd man the professor. It's almost as if he's holding onto a very dark secret or something. And I bet you anything that the girl he identified at the morgue, wasn't his daughter. This man's obsession with finding a new face for his daughter has borderline sociopathic/psychopathic tendencies written all over it. An obsessed scientist trying to prove his own theory on facial reconstruction surgery. Part caring father, part obsessive sociopath. Very creepy and unsettling when she puts the mask on Christiane and starts brushing her hair, with the almost lullaby music playing in the background. Christiane's a typical case of the monster that's kept locked up in the room/dungeon/attic "for her own good". It's ironic cuz I can tell Christiane is beautiful - or was beautiful before the car accident, her eyes at least seem very pretty. And it seems like her father is to blame for all of this due to the way he drove the car that fateful night. So he's most likely feeling some sort of guilt.

I think they actually used a mold to create the mask since it perfectly contours and fits the shape of her face. It's so weird how much the secretary and the girl they're trying to subdue look alike. It's almost like the secretary could be her mother. I can't believe the actresses are not related in real life. God that's terrifying, the stuff of real life nightmares. To meet a charismatic stranger you think is trying to help you out but really they're just luring you into a trap. Those poor dogs - caged up just like Christiane. Only their cages are smaller, much uncomfortably smaller. It's no wonder she has a natural bond with them - they're both in similar situations. 

What really sells that operation scene isn't the blood or the prosthetics (which is noticeably fake lol) - it's the silence. There's no music. Just the professor's heavy breathing and the clanking of the surgery instruments. It's brilliant. They could have easily used some sort of eerie music to build the tension, but I think going with the silence made the scene much more effective and tense. Damn, that really sucks. I thought the operation was a success but it turned out the graft rejected the tissue. I feel bad for Christiane. There was a glimmer of hope for her, and now she's back at square one. I was really looking forward to her starting a new life. Call it karmic justice the way the dog's ravaged the professors face once they were freed by Christiane. I love how she walks away into the forrest with the animals - now accepting of her situation. 

Really tight and effective storytelling, quite captivating actually - poetic. Even though it kind of dragged for a couple of minutes towards the 1 hour and 15 minute mark, I never really felt bored watching it. Every scene has its purpose that contributes to the overall story and its subject matter is pretty dark and shocking - especially considering the time it came out in 1960. I bet there hadn't been another movie quite like this one at the time of its release. It's basically like a grounded in reality retelling of Frankenstein. The composition of the shots are very well thought out. I really liked the shot of the cemetery as the professor and his secretary are leaving - with those dead ominous-looking trees and the car in frame between the gate. Really terrific use of creepy imagery and fantastic use of lighting. This movie could serve as pretty good commentary on animal testing, like from makeup companies or skin product companies. As well as good commentary on car crash facial reconstruction surgery victims. I do feel like the music choice could have been better. I felt that it didn't really compliment the overall creepy tone of the movie. It was too playful and jaunty sounding, like something you'd hear in a circus arena. And on top of that they kept playing the same tune throughout the movie several times. Other than that, I thought the movie was a terrifically creepy journey through one girl's tragic circumstance and an obsessive scientist/father's desire to help his daughter but also prove his theory and advance science. A great depiction of a real-life horror situation that can happen to anyone involved in an accident. Although I don't think I'd own it on physical Criterion blu ray, I would like to have a download of it.
More art-house in design than the advertising blurb I read before seeing this film suggested, nonetheless it's a good effort.
Subtle horror blend with a chilled thrill. The movie which must have inspired Pedro Almodovar's The Skin I Live In.
The chilling fairy tale esque storytelling creates an unsettling tone throughout. Disturbing imagery and subtext are the icing on the cake.
Creepy and slightly disturbing French horror film about a rogue surgeon who conducts facial transplants in the secrecy of his own home. The patients and their transplanted faces are downright creepy.

Saw it on halloween, looking for that spooky vibe. This is known as a horror classic, at least a pretty grim piece with some nasty stills.

A terrific story, where a doctor tries to save his pretty daughters face. She was in some sort of accident, but he failed to fix it the first time. Now she has a wound as a face - no skin at all. She has to wear a mask as her father tries to find suitable girls to steal faces from. Edith Scob as Christiane has the loveliest of all faces, though.

Very influentional mask, it's been seen in a lot of movies and loads of known films has used it as inspiration. The "Halloween" series is probably the most famous one, but films like "Under The Skin" and "Holy Motors" has clear referances too.

That operating scene is pretty unsettling, back in the days it must have been a true shocker. Now it's just pretty creepy and well executed.  Not directly scary since it never got that shock feature - a good thing. The vibe is still uncomfortable and the shooting in total are very good. It looks perfect in black and white - I can't imagine it being done in color actually. The cool theme song needs a mention, and so does the lovely ending.

7.5 out of 10 doves.
Eyes Without a Face is cinematic prose.
Great effects and style, the stiff editing and Gothic archetypes are dated.
Finally a horror movie to shout from the rooftops. Bleak, atmospheric, disturbing and intoxicating, this is truly one of a kind.
eye without face more liek kys

WHOA! Great effects, and such a sinister twist.
Nice work for creating creepy so well.
Eyes Without a Face is a disturbing and graceful near-masterwork of the visual, of what its images show and what they suggest.
A disturbing and discomforting horror flick with great tension and suspense throughout.

I'm not sure the story is fulfilled as much as it could be, but there is some really interesting stuff in this film and I think it's a pretty big inspiration to some modern Horror films in this department.
There is something creepy and uncomfortable in watching this film -

Controversial when first released in 1959 for its violent content and disturbing subject matter, Eyes Without a Face is still as unnerving a genre film as ever. Taking the "mad scientist" template and applying it to the world of plastic surgery, the film explores  themes concerning beauty and obsession, and features ravishing images. There's just so many unforgettable moments of poeticism in the film too, including an ending that remains one of the most iconic conclusions in French cinema. A minor masterpiece, and perhaps the most obvious precursor to the giallo era.

A chilling & suspenseful film about a genius doctor who is obsessed with finding the right face for a transplant for his disfigured daughter's face.

The atmosphere of the film is so tense & the performance of the young girl disfigured is sensational since she is mainly masked but her acting just beams out of her.

Quite sordid & dark for its day due to the controversial face transplant sequence, but it's the story & performances that make this film so engaging. A French classic Horror....
Poetic French art film at its finest. A gruesome and creepy film that keeps you in suspense.

Eyes Without a Face is a special kind of horror movie that is at times truly frightening and at others, incredibly beautiful. Pushing the boundaries for the time, Georges Franju crafts an unbelievably effective movie that holds up today as one of the most unnerving yet rewarding movie experiences.
Middling French horror film with too little suspense. Dramatic ending is the best part.

Crazy, unforgettably disturbing, artistically rich: "Eyes Without a Face" is the rare horror film that manages to exceed your desire for a perfect marriage of uncompromising brutality and elegantly poetic grace.

3.6/5
A fairly basic tale with powerful performances and terrifying moments.
Got no human grace, your eyes without a face

A clear classic in its own right -- unsettling, disquieting, poetic, horrifying, anguished, tragic. Yet it is done so unassumingly, so directly. That may bring in some of the alien, frightening element. There's so much here, conceptually and visually, it is eerily, darkly fascinating & compelling. And it works visually so well that it could work as a silent film. Tremendous body acting by Edith Scob. This film is unflinching, yet has the subtlety of true art. 4-4.5.

It is hard watching a movie so sad.  For a horror movie that shows almost nothing, so much discomfort and uneasiness is instilled.

The characterization is wonderful in this.  The surgeon is clearly insane, but he loves his daughter so much and wants her to be able to be in the public again, beautiful as she was.  The daughter, herself, is in a deep depression over the suffering of having lost her beauty.  

Then there is the police trying to find a killer who is removing the faces of young beautiful women.

Really wonderful, and tragic story.

Ambitious horror pic [from the novel by Jean Redon] depends on clinical operation scenes and the showing of deformed faces for its effect. It has some queasy scenes, but unclear progression and plodding direction give this an old-fashioned air.

Such a shockingly beautiful film.  It was hard for me to appreciate the beauty and the horror that lies within.  If you ever question can art house and horror coexist, this movie will give you a definitive answer.

A classic French horror film. It kind of relies on old cliches, while updating it for a modern audience (for the time). The mad scientist has been done since the beginning of horror films, but here the mad scientist acts relatively normal, and is just psychotic underneath the surface. He goes about his daily routine and he never becomes a ranting lunatic (he kinda walks a fine line, but it never goes overboard). The look of Christiane (the girl without a face) is classic, iconic, and creepy. She's not really the villain of this movie or a monster, but she deserves a place alongside Dracula, Frankenstein, the Bride, and the Invisible Man as an iconic horror character. The movie has a lot of subtext to it. There's a theme of vanity and that to be normal is to look beautiful and perfect, but Christiane is the most normal of her small family despite being the one disfigured. The surgery scene is another great scene, and considering the year this was made it's impressive and bloody. One of the great surgery scenes in film. There are plenty of great shots and the pacing is pretty good, though it drags a bit in the third act when they're like, "Well, I guess we need another girl's face to cut off!" The music is a not very fitting and actually sounds like the theme to Curb Your Enthusiasm. It's unintentionally funny. Before re-watching this, I would have been quick to put Eyes Without a Face up there with the classics. Now, I'm a bit unsure. It's still very good for its time and one of the absolute best of the decade, but it doesn't quite reach the level of Psycho, Rosemary's Baby, or Night of the Living Dead. Looking at this movie now, it's more on the level of Village of the Damned and Carnival of Souls. Very, very good 60s horror movies that are under appreciated. Still, Eyes Without a Face is another movie that shows a horror revolution that started in the early 60s, not the 70s.
An oldie but a goodie. However it was not scary, just odd. 1001 movies to see before you die.

Sadly I'm not sure what practically everyone sees in this movie.  I think part of the problem is that it was so heavily hyped that I was bound to end up being a bit disappointed.  Chilling?  Disturbing?  No, except for for a creepy face transplant scene that had a sort of timeless, modern feel to it.  The rest of this movie doesn't work with dull, one-note characters and weak dialogue that left me with the feeling that this film is dated and old fashioned.  This movie doesn't allow the viewer to connect to any of the characters nor does it provide the sort of atmosphere that such a movie should have, regardless of whether one considers this a horror movie or psychological thriller.  Either way, I would recommend watching something else.
Not a horror film, but a surrealist fantasy!
One of the most beautiful "horror" movies ever made.

Eyes without a Face (or "Les yeux sans visage") is a 1959 French/Italian horror film about a renowned surgeon who kidnaps young women and tries to graph their faces on to that of his daughters, who's own face was left horrible disfigured after a car wreck that her father was responsible for. Touching, isn't it? Considered extremely controversial for 1959, this horror film didn't just get negative reviews by critics, it was outright hated by them in both France and America. All the controversy was over one surgery scene in which a girl gets her face sliced off. It was pretty graphic and I can see why it would cause a flare amongst critics and moviegoers of the late 50's. But this was marketed as a horror film and they're suppose to shock and thrill you. One theater reported that seven people fainted during the scene, so I guess you could say it was the Hostel of it's time. The scene looks pretty realistic and even made me cringe up a bit. But this one scene is about as violent as it gets, the rest of the film is pretty mild aside from the ending. The film does drag on from time to time but it makes up for it with well character development, especially Dr. GÃ©nessier and Christiane, the two main characters in the film. Dr. GÃ©nessier (Pierre Brassuer) isn't the typical run of the mill mad scientist we're so use to seeing in horror films. Here we see someone who is calm and quit-witted, but also grief-stricken at the fact that this is all his fault and he doesn't take pleasure kid-napping women and preforming surgery on them, but feels he must to atone for his carelessness. Christiane (Edith Scob), daughter to the good doctor, wears a white mask through about 90% of the film. The mask is a perfect mold of the actresses own face which makes it look very natural and this mask would later serve as an inspiration for the mask used in Halloween, as stated by John Carpenter. Christiane's movement throughout the film is very fluent and dream-like, Edith Scob does a great job of showing emotion through body language as a substitution for lack of facial expression. Her character doesn't actually play the villain, she's more of the protagonist if anything. She spends most of her time alone in her room nursing her many pet doves and trying to come to terms with her disfigurement. The musical score did need to improving, in my opinion it sounds a little like circus music. It's isn't very menacing, but isn't too out of place either. The dialogue is pretty good, but it does get over dramatic at times. However, it is in the french language (which I dont speak) with English subtitles, so I feel my criticism wouldn't do justice on this. The film sends a pretty powerful message that beauty comes from within and to accept your fate, and accept yourself for who you are. Seeking outer beauty can sometimes come at a high cost, so high that it eventually turns you into something ugly. Overall this is a great film in regards to acting, special effects, set design and atmosphere. It does lack a lot of the scares of your typical horror film, but this was done intentionally to be able to pass the censors for screening to make up for the surgery scene. That's what I love about a lot of foreign films, especially from France, Italy or Japan. They aren't afraid to take a risk at something no one wants to try. And if you take a look at the new wave of French horror now, you will see a glaring difference between it and American horror. Far more originality and far more shocking. They don't sellout by making a billion different zombie and demon possession movies that try to out do The Exorcist and Night of the Living Dead like we do over here. Instead they just move on to new ideas. We could stand to learn a lot from the French. Sorry to say, but they got us beat when it comes to horror and always have. Eyes without a Face is definitely a film to watch if you like classic B&W horror as well as being a great starting point if you're interested in dipping into French horror. Though it isn't a horror film that everyone will enjoy, it is a good film regardless of genre. French horror probably wouldn't be so shocking if they didn't have this film as a blueprint.

Les Yeux Sans Visage was one of the greatest revivals of the German expressionist cinema. It is a tale of a surgeon father's guilt over his daughter's disfiguring accident who began kidnapping girls to transplant their faces to her. I adored the cinematography overall, it sends you a chill to your spine without any gore and the poetic justice served the film well.

Unlike typical horror fare, Eyes Without a Face eschews the rote jump-scares and hokey sentimentality in favor of quietly unsettling drama, looking to create a lasting sense of anxiety that is much more poignant. The visuals are iconic, the mask a lasting influence on the genre and the elegiac ending's imagery an understated summation of the film's mission statement culminated in near-perfect fashion.

Rare are french horror film, and never good they are. But "Eyes without a face" is an exception made in the french Nouvelle Vague area. Impressively gory and poetic, with a touch of slasher horror film.

http://letterboxd.com/zbender/film/eyes-without-a-face/


"The spectators dropped like flies." -L'Express, a French magazine.

This quote was featured in a film essay by David Kalat a film historian. The Criterion Collection is a great companion piece if you are interested in learning more about film theory, or just learning more than from your average wiki article. It was a stark reminder of just how controversial a film like Eyes Without a Face was way back when. Georges Franju's vision, while perhaps being a bit of a let down in its first thirty minutes, escalates quickly. The dark imagery and some of the horrid shots was a game changer in the genre. Hell, a horror film that relies on its visuals and tone rather than the jump scare aspect seems like a horror film of note. And this one deserves all its attention.
Haven't gotten the chills from a movie since before I was 20

A deranged surgical genius (Pierre Brasseur) is abducting and murdering young ladies in the hopes that he can perform a successful face transplant upon his disfigured daughter (Edith Scob). That sounds like a plot point for an 1980's slasher movie or a 2000's torture porn feature, but Eyes WIthout A Face is often lumped in with the artful experimentation of the French New Wave. What you'll see when you watch this movie is a demonstration in fierce contrasts; a gory horror film is framed with techniques and character-building that come straight out of the arthouse. The result is a film that is thoughtful, contemplative, and squirm-inducing.

Not the groundbreaking masterpiece I was led to believe it was. But still a good horror flick, some really unnerving scenery in it, that I'm sure would have taken its toll on audiences back in the day.
A somewhat creepy tale that is almost like Frankenstein in a way. Also surprising to see how far the filmmakers took some aspects of the film.

Only the French (+Italian, credit were credits due) can make a horror film with such poetic beauty, as-well as combining all the fields together - gore, suspense and drama. One of the greatest films I have seen. Delicate then horrific, just fantastic.

You know a movie is old when all the credits are at the beginning. According to Complex it's one of "The 50 Most Disturbing Movies". The face removal scene was probably disturbing in the 60's, but Brakhage blew it out of the water with The Act of Seeing with One's Own Eyes in 1971. If you are looking for weird old colorless French stuff, check out Un Chien Andalou, it's much shorter and more disturbing. For a shocking captive surgery drama watch The Skin I Live In instead.
Well this one is creepy.

Art House cinema meets B-Movie Horror in Georges Franju's iconic masterwork. Franju's film is a lyrical chiller well ahead of its time, driven by antagonists and bathed in an air of disconcerting distrust.
The concept's sky-high, the plots far-fetched, but this is a tragedy that's truly poetic throughout; equally menacing as it is both alluring and utterly unique. There are times you just won't know whether to laugh or to cry. Influential, essential cinema.

After his daughter is horribly disfigured in a car accident, a surgeon attempts to fix her by grafting on the faces of unwilling local girls.
Incredibly creepy & twisted, this only feels like a horror movie because of the plot. Most horror movies are stylized with a tinge of German expressionism, but this is filmed very straight-forward. There's a creepy score of organ-grinder carnival music, and you scarred girl floats moves around the house like a ghostly apparition haunting her former life. He has 15 dogs in cages which is unsettling...Oh no...he's removing a girls face....OH GOD THEY'RE REMOVING HER FACE!! WHY IS THIS TAKING SO LONG? IT'S BEEN LIKE 7 MINUTES! OH GOD THIS IS LIKE A SURGICAL SNUFF FILM!...
...Okay, I'm back. So yeah, after watching him surgically remove a girls face, this it totally a horror movie. Like a French suburban drama mixed with some human centipede. Also, possibly the stupidest detectives in movie history, and that's saying something. (Sidenote, the movie was the inspiration for the Billy Idol ballad of the same name.)
Too slow for this cowpoke.  Although, had one very unsettling scene.
A great classic chilling horror that's both twisted and haunting but even artistic.
It's as much about what you don't see as what you do.

87%
Atmospheric yet ultimately bittersweet, Eyes Without A Face contains some of the most graphic visuals in film, and also has a moving story and rich performances help advance the thin plot.

It's going to be one of my braver moments of film criticism when I say that I didn't like this "horror classic." Perhaps it was because I was very tired while I was watching and after a while I was trying to not to fall asleep. I may have to re-watch it when I'm less tired. But the sad truth is that on my first viewing Eyes Without a face wasn't good enough to keep me from falling asleep. Eyes Without a Face tells the tale of a doctor and his horribly disfigured daughter. He and his assistant kidnap young women and surgically remove their faces in order to transplant them onto daughter. It's a very creepy premise and there were many elements of this that I did like. It looks brilliant! Eyes Without a Face is shot and lighted in ways that were ahead of its time, creating a wonderful mood and sense of atmosphere. In fact the most interesting and most terrifying scenes are all visual. The mask worn by the disfigured daughter is one of the creepiest things I've ever seen in a film. It looks so life-like and yet completely inhuman at the same time. And then there's the surgery scene, where the doctor cuts off the victims face and its shown in as much detail as possible. But the unfortunately thing is, underneath all the fantastic imagery there's not enough content to sustain an entire film. First off, I never really felt like I actually knew any of these characters. They all have their role but beyond that I didn't ever see the human beings behind them. The story itself only has a bullet-point narrative, getting us from point a to point b without any reason for us care about what's happening. And finally it's really very padded. There are a lot of sequences that just shows one character moving from one location to the next. They are meant to build up suspense but I just became bored and tired of it, wanting the film to move on to the next scene. These problems really cut into the best parts of the film and keep it from working as a whole. I really hate to call a film with this much going for essentially shallow, but that was my impression of Eyes Without a Face. Maybe my second viewing will give me so much more, but as of now I cannot call Eyes Without a Face the masterpiece it has so often been touted as.
A thought provoking, disturbing masterpiece of horror.
A brilliant concept with acceptable execution is still a fairly good movie.
Must have traumatized the audiences when it was first released! And knowing that tickled my fancy to no end!

Dated? I'll say! I was really looking forward to this Criterion version of the highly praised horror film. Boy was I disappointed! SLOOOWWWW to say the least and to me just an average film. CERTAINLY not the classic it was made out to be. Ken K

It wasn't what I expected, but still it was a very stylish movie with a simple story, that easily could've been more interesting and more developed. Still, it had some very interesting and memorable imagery, that were timeless and very beautiful in an odd way, for example when Christiane wears her mask with her very elegant and big coat two sizes too big. 
~June 3, 2014~

This french film is a hitchcockian monster movie, a campy,suspenseful frankenstein murder mystery. A loving father transforms into a fiendish mad scientist as he & his beautiful assistant kidnap young girls to be unwilling donors for his daughter's face transplant. His daughter floats around like a trapped ghost, with an emotionless mask & ethereal white nightgown. Is she his motivation, or just an experiment?

I'm perplexed at how such a widely renowned film could bore me to tears, let alone a film that is called a poetic masterpiece by Criterion. I find myself grasping at the excuse that I first watched the film over 50 years from it's release. Am I desensitized to it's dread and "gore" that at the time was monumental? I say not so. I've been gripped by films made a decade before this was conceived, so why was I not moved by Franju's vision? I admit there were moments of human sorrow that tugged at my heartstrings, but mere seconds in a sea of drudging scenes? After viewing; minutes passes, hours passed, and time continued to move on while this film left a strange aftertaste in my mind. This is where the most credit I can place shall lay. I found this film un-engaging to watch, and that is exactly the same position our faceless protagonist feels about living her life. In that, "Eyes Without a Face" succeeds in one of the most important aspects of storytelling: putting the audience in a character's shoes.
One of the most underappreciated horror films of all time. It is creepy for today's age, let alone in the 1960s. It will leave you with unpleasant memories for all your days.

Creeping, poetic French horror that wears classical inspirations on its sleeve while trying to nudge the genre along in bleak new directions. It's a mixed bag, really. The superficial elements - framing, effects, visual themes - are top notch, real cutting edge stuff for the period. The sympathetic lead, a young woman whose face was ravaged by a violent car accident, wears a fragile, unsettling China doll mask to conceal her disfigurements. It's an especially powerful effect when combined with the rich black-and-white film stock, which makes it difficult to determine where the mask ends and her flesh begins. Late in the picture, as the girl's mad surgeon of a father graphically peels the skin away from an unwilling donor to "fix" his daughter's wounds, it's tough not to flinch. The scene, and the concept, is that convincing, that unnerving. The plot suffers from a serious lack of depth, however, retreading the same territory several times before making any progress, and the film plods along for too long as a result. A terribly loud, mismatched score further sours matters, flooding the room with brow-furrowing carnival music at regular intervals. It's a curious relic, one which clearly influenced a whole new generation of filmmakers in the years after its release, but probably works better as an exercise of original theories than a complete picture.

Depicts an obsession that is not only horrific due to the actions taken, but because of the guilt that those actions entail.
Full Review: http://tylerdscreation.wordpress.com/2014/05/19/eyes-without-a-face-1960-review/

Eyes Without a Face (Les yeux sans visage, 1960) - 7

A mask wearing young woman, brutally disfigured in a car accident. The father, a brilliant surgeon who attempts to give new beauty to his beloved daughter by kidnapping and surgically stealing the faces of other beautiful young women. An horror movie from 1960, exploring the fine layer between beauty and grotesque. Very interesting the way how this movie manages to turn beautiful into horrendous and vice-versa. Pleasently surprised by it's apparent seriousness, it didn't fall for the mistake of comical skittishness as I'd expect for such a movie, pretty sober stuff. It never really spooked the hell out of my and it was somewhat predictable, but I really appreciated how it handled the goriest and spookier moments, nothing to obvious, the director was smart enough to play with subtlety, suggestion and expectation. And yet, some viewers might be surprised with the level of gore detail present in this 1960 movie!

An Horror movie it might be, but odd as it may sound, the greatest impression I came out of it was of its aesthetical appeal and beauty... there's a certain enchantment here stemming from the great cinematic sensibility of Georges Franju, camera work and photography (German Expressionism). This made the movie worth to me, despite the mindless script. I say mindless script because I never felt there was a true purpose or intent behind the majority of the events in the movie, a simple succession determined by basic and cliché writing, but beautifully carved to enhance the visual appeal of it. This movie is an interesting stylistic exercise in the Horror genre. I liked it and highly recommend it to lovers of Classic black-and-white Cinema. And of course fans of Horror.
Not scary or shocking, kinda poorly shot, but memorable images here and there.

There is some nice visual poetry toward the end that ties this up and gives it a nearly fairy-tale feel, but most of the movie dragged for me. The central conflict is interesting, overtly psychological, but the characters are just way too stilted, and have far too little dialogue, for those aspects to really speak. More importantly, for whatever reason the creepy aspects (mask, scarred face, surgery porn), didn't have much effect on me.

It's central theme is on the money (Genessier's guilt over causing the accident which disfigured his daughter) and also the progression of his treatment of his daughter like a laboratory animal (also on the money). What is a letdown is the at times rather naive and pretty old fashioned storytelling (exposition abounds & and the police work is done particularly vague). The direction has some nice moments, but overall it's not that interesting and the viewer is always ahead thanks to the story being minimal and predictable, and not only predictable but paced like a snail. The acting can't really be talked about in any superlative way, as it's pretty flat. As an idea, Eyes Without a Face has a certain draw but the film underwhelms in almost every way.
Disturbing, yet shows pretty much nothing.  Love it.

Brilliant and stunning Foreign Horror film brilliantly directed by Georges Franju, Eyes Without a Face is a unique film in the genre. Beautifully filmed an acted, this is one of the most powerful genre films in the medium. Using images to create its terror as it is a very subtle film that manages to truly terrify the viewer with atmosphere, and the fear of what is transpiring what keeps you involved from start to finish. The cast is phenomenal and the lead actress, Edith Scob delivers a powerful performance in the role Christiane Génessierm, the daughter of a mad doctor who is deformed and whose father captures young women to find a perfect face for his daughter. The film may seem tame by today's standards, but at the time of its release, the film was ahead of its time. This is horror the way it should be. Franju direction is immaculate, and his eye for creating a truly memorable and engaging horror film is unmatched. Eyes Without a Face is a flawless picture that is both beautiful and shocking all at once. The images that befall upon you are haunting, disturbing and unforgettable. Eyes Without a Face is a brilliant picture that tells a subtle, yet horrifying story that will certainly appeal to viewers looking for a truly well executed picture that uses the bare necessities to create terrific terror. The result here is a truly disturbing, yet brilliant affair that is among the finest horror films ever made. If you get a chance at seeing this iconic film, you'll glad you did. Using horror basics, Franju was able to make a film that has much more impact on the viewer than many of the horror films released today.
Has lost none of it's power to shock and awe.
A French 'Sweeney Todd'.
Carefully paced, poetic in nature, beautifully filmed, and yet absolutely terrifying, Eyes Without a Face is a horror gem, honoring the years of German Expressionism
Eyes is an eerie masterstroke of both the art house and horror realms. A film that will get under your skin...no pun intended.

This highly underrated French film has finally been given a proper restoration by Criterion. While Georges Franju is working within the "horror" genre, EYES WITHOUT A FACE far exceeds the boundaries. It is actually more of a Surrealist Gothic Adult Fairy Tale. The film has a consistently dream-like quality that will haunt the viewer's mind long after watching it. Surprisingly graphic for a film from 1960, Edith Scob and her iconic mask still pack a punch. You almost want to follow her as she sort of floats down the country path with newly freed birds. Excellent film.

Eyes Without a Face is to be appreciated for being so daring and disturbing for its time,  (it still holds up to this day in those regards), but there really just wasn't enough material in it for me to sink my teeth into.  It's good, but a bit overrated among critics, in my opinion.
A beautifully terrifying fairytale.
Eyes without a Face is a tactful piece of horror that has influenced modern films of the genre.
